oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Tom T. Hall Interview by Bob Allen 1-15-82 - Side Two
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is an interview of Tom T. Hall by Bob Allen. The interview takes place on 1-15-82.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Tom T. Hall;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Tape One, Side Two - (0:00) -- First four minutes of tape are muffled by tape warping. Skip to (4:00) -- Beginning of discussion about Don Schlitz's song, "The Gambler." (5:40) -- Tom T. Hall mentions that he believes that country music songwriters are "of a certain mentality." Tom T. Hall describes how time often restricts the content of a song. (7:03) -- Bob Allen mentions to Tom T. Hall one of Tom's quotes claiming "writing a book was in some ways like writing a series of songs with narratives." (7:41) -- Bob Allen asks Tom T. Hall whether he ever turned down gigs/bookings to write his book. Tom T. Hall mentions that he's had a desire to write a book since the age of nine years old. (11:04) -- Tom T. Hall tells a story about his son reading his novel. (12:19) -- Bob Allen asks about Tom T. Hall's character development for his novel. Tom T. Hall speaks about a novelist's complete creative control. (16:41) -- Bob Allen asks Tom T. Hall to contrast his fictional town from his novel and his personal memories of Kentucky. (18:33) -- Bob Allen asks about Tom T. Hall's childhood themes present in Tom's songwriting. Tom T. Hall says that he tries to remember the reality of his childhood as supposed to embellishing the past. (21:10) -- Bob Allen asks Tom T. Hall whether the best way to emphasize an emotion in a song is to ignore it. (23:33) -- Bob Allen describes the imagery present in Tom T. Hall's song "The Year That Clayton Delaney Died." (24:01) -- Tom T. Hall mentions Billy Joe Schaffer's song "Old Five And Dimers Like Me." (26:26) -- Bob Allen asks Tom T. Hall about his complex narrative techniques present in his songwriting. Tom T. Hall mentions that one of his favorite lines he's ever written is "Temporary lookin' houses with their lean and bashful kids" - from "Trip To Hyden" by Tom T. Hall. (28:16) -- Bob Allen speaks about the first time he heard "Trip To Hyden." (29:49) -- Bob Allen asks Tom T. Hall's about the origins of writing complex songwriting narratives. Tom T. Hall mentions his song "Ballad Of Forty Dollars." (35:14) -- Bob Allen asks Tom T. Hall about his family's creative background. (36:44) -- Tom T. Hall speaks about his family tree. (40:40) -- Tom T. Hall speaks about his memory of minor scenarios from his life influencing his songwriting. (43:00) -- Tom T. Hall speaks about the impact of his song "Harper Valley PTA."
